Detailed Description

This class is used to present & validate forms. Processing of the data is, for the most part, not handled by this class. A very simple processing to submit into a database is available via the processSimple method but anything more complex should be done elsewhere.

Todo:

create method to use multidimensional array in a SELECT element

create method to make nested checkboxes via nested OLs

create method to make two-column checkbox options

prevent consumer idiocy by checking for 'value' as a key on $inputAttrs and stripping it

dateDropSet (   $label,
  $settings,
  $varname,

  $labelAttrs = null,
  $postString = '' 
)

SELECT ELEMENT - DATE This presents a SET of dropdowns for date This is based on HTML4 and does not do any of the new HTML5 hotness this creates a set of three dropdowns for month, day, and year

Todo:
there appears to be no way to add inputAttrs to the elements
Parameters
string $label the text label (for the entire set
array $settings array of settings with the following keys array $daydrop settings for use in creating the day dropdown array $monthdrop settings for use in creating the month dropdown array $yeardrop settings for use in creating the year dropdown string $varname name of this element set, for use in printing validation warnings string $order pipe delimited list, used to order these elements MUST be pipe-delimited and MUST contain ONLY the words "month", "day", and "year", separated by pipes
$varname
array $wrapperAttrs array of attributes for the wrapper
array $labelAttrs array of attributes for the labels
string $postString
daydrop (   $settings )

creates a dropdown menu for picking the day called as a portion of a date dropdown set

Parameters
array $settings array of settings with the following keys 'name' - the select element's 'name' attribute value 'id' - the select element's 'id' attribute value 'default_label' - the default label for an empty <option> 'label' - the text label for this element 'default' - the default value 'extras' - anything extra appended to the <select> element, such as javascript
Returns
string the $output variable is populated with the HTML

prints the form to the page

SELECT ELEMENT (normal) Prints an HTML <select> element and all its related <option> elements In this case, the <option> elements utilize an array which has no associative keys.

SELECT ELEMENT - uses the pipe method for different values than labels uses an array like 'item1|1' and makes '<option value="1">item1</option>' prints an HTML <select> element, with all its related <options> different from above in the manner which it handles the option values

enforceInputType ( &  $attrs )
protected

Ensures that if there's no type supplied, it is set to 'text'. Necessary for certain HTML5 magic

formExp (   $string,
  $attrs = null,
  $nowrap = false 
)

creates text (or anything) inside a form, helps avoid breaking the form especially when the form is laid out in a table

Parameters
string $string the stuff being printed
null $attrs
bool $nowrap allows for the string to be included raw with no wrapping stuff. typically a bad idea, but adds flexibility (i.e. including datalists)
formStart (   $pretext = '',
  $formAttrs = null,
  $wrapAttrs = null,
  $extras = '' 
)

gets the beginning of a form

Parameters
string $pretext arbitrary string of stuff to put before the form (such as instructions)
array $formAttrs attributes for the FORM element
array $wrapAttrs attributes for whatever the wrapper element is
string $extras arbitrary string of stuff (such as javascript) for the FORM element
formWarn (   $msg = null,
  $attrs = null 
)

creates a user friendly warning message that one or more items failed validation this is intended to go above the entire form to serve as a global message

Parameters
string $msg the validation warning message
array $attrs attributes for the DIV that holds the message

setPresets (   $array )

This sets the values for all of the elements on the form using an associative array the key for each item in the array needs to match the 'name' attribute for each element

Parameters
array $array
setRequiredAttr ( &  $attrs )
protected

This method helps to ensure that if the required attribute is not already set in the attributes array that it gets added. Also sets aria-required at the same time.

We only do a very simple check here that its set. There is no validation that the value is correct as we assume if you screw that up then there's a reason for you to have done so.
